awd_titl_txt: Multiple Consciousnesses: Investigating The Identities (Academic, Gender, Race and Disability) Of Black Women Undergraduate Students In STEM And Their Impact On Persistence
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program supports research projects that seek to study the  underlying issues affecting the differential participation and graduation rates in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate education of African American students.  This award to Howard University is co-funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, specifically the ECR Research in Disabilities Education area of special interest. ECR emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field. Howard University has teamed with three other Historically Black Universities - Morgan State University, Hampton University, and Prairie View A & M University - to conduct a large empirical study of Black women undergraduate students in STEM. The overall goal of the project is to investigate the intersectionality of their existing identities (gender, race and disability) and the identity that they acquire as STEM students on their way to earning a degree and the impact of the intersectionality on their participation, retention and success. The project is guided by an evaluator, as well as an external advisory committee. 

For decades, researchers have examined the issues related to broadening the participation, retention, and success of individuals underrepresented in STEM. However, there is limited data on Black women, who over time have become an increasingly larger portion of the available talent pool. Past research on women and Blacks in STEM has not focused on the identities of race, gender and disability. The identity of being Black and female uniquely influences the pathways that students take to reach degree goals and be successful in STEM careers. The study will investigate the impacts of the intersectionality of existing identities (gender, race and disability) and the academic identity that they acquire as STEM students. The researchers will use a triangulation mixed methods approach to longitudinally collect qualitative and quantitative data to learn participants' perspectives and experiences from freshman to senior year. Additionally, those participants who self-identify as a person with disabilities will be invited to participate in a semi-structured interview. Purposive sampling will be employed to ensure an adequate number of students with disabilities participate in the project's qualitative data collection. Once data are collected and disaggregated, the variance in the educational experiences of students along the variables of ethnicity, racial identity, gender identity, disability, and academic major will be examined. It is anticipated that a better understanding of the complexity of the identities of these women will inform inclusion practices, particularly at the collegiate level, and perhaps serve as a predictive element in success.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this mixed-methods longitudinal study was to explore the gender, racial, and academic identities of Black women enrolled in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduate programs at historically Black colleges/universities (HBCUs). This three-year study captured Black women's unique experiences within STEM programs, while focusing on how their academic and social experiences contributed to their STEM identity development, achievement, and persistence.

The data are rich in participants' descriptions of the multiplicity of their social identities, the meaning they ascribe to being a Black woman in STEM, the role of their institutions in their STEM success, and their identified sources of STEM motivation. One noteworthy theme was the role of intersecting social identities in participants' decisions to pursue STEM. Salient social identities informed the value participants ascribed to a STEM major, and in turn, activated their STEM pursuit motivation. These women described their motivation in relation to the importance a STEM major held for a particular social group to which they belonged. Often, the participants recounted their motivation to pursue STEM at the intersection of two or more social identities, such as Black and first-generation college student, or Black, woman, and urban community member.

Participants' responses also illustrated a dichotomy between predominantly Black STEM learning environments and the STEM workforce as it relates gender and racial identity salience and STEM identity development. The HBCU context allowed participants to study STEM and further develop their STEM identity without their race, gender, or the intersection of the two, creating experiences disruptive to their identity development. Participants' institutions were also praised for climates of excellence and the overall cultural wealth of the STEM learning environments. Black women in this study spoke of their institution's role in encouraging their STEM persistence. The opportunity to see themselves reflected in their STEM programs was a prominent means for acquiring aspirational capital through their predominantly Black campuses.

Intellectual Merit: This project extends extant work on Black women in STEM undergraduate programs by situating the investigation in predominantly Black learning environments. The literature on Black women's experiences in STEM higher education programs is replete with investigations of racialized and gendered microaggressions or discriminatory experiences that impede their STEM success, persistence, and achievement at predominantly White institutions (PWIs). The findings from this study present a counter-narrative for Black women in STEM and illuminate the cultural wealth of HBCU environments. Lastly, the work informs researchers' understanding of what uniquely attracts Black women and girls to STEM. In grappling with our country's inability to produce and retain diverse STEM talent, policymakers, researchers, and educators will benefit from this work in their attempts to develop interventions and recruitment strategies to attract women of color to STEM fields.

Broader Impacts: Research on the identities of Black women and their STEM success also contributes to a broader range of disciplines. Sociologists and anthropologists who focus on social structures and cultural forces that underlie human behavior may benefit from conversations on how Black women in STEM live at the intersections of various social identities and their underlying social influences. The results of this study may also encourage scholars interested in identity development to attend more to social identities other than race/ethnicity. Finally, developmental psychologists and others who follow an ecological view of human development may also benefit from a greater understanding of how social identities are constructed or maintained across distinct learning environments.

The research team disseminated data from this project through an international conference proceeding and a peer-reviewed journal publication. In July 2019, a member of the research team presented a paper at the 8th Research in Engineering Education Symposium (REES) entitled, "The Impact of the Combined Status of Race and Gender on the Persistence of Black Female STEM Students". The Journal of Negro Education (JNE) published a summer issue in 2019 entitled, Identity Formations of African American STEM Majors. Our research team published an article in this issue on the intersectionality of racial, gender, academic, and STEM identities among Black women in STEM disciplines. In the upcoming months, the team will submit at least two additional manuscripts for publication.

Boakye, B., Smith, K.C., Williams, D., & Fleming, L. (2019). The impact of the combined status of race and gender on the persistence of Black female STEM students. Research in Engineering Education Symposium, Cape Town, South Africa. Status = PUBLISHED; Acknowledgment of Federal Support = Yes; Peer Reviewed = Yes

Smith, K.C., Boakye, B., Williams, D., & Fleming, L. (2019). The exploration of how identity intersectionality strengthens STEM identity for Black female undergraduates attending a historically Black college and university (HBCU). The Journal of Negro Education, 88, 407-418. Doi:10.7709/jnegroeducation.88.3.0407


Last Modified: 01/25/2022
Modified by: Lorraine N Fleming
